DataElement.preferredName: Genome Assembly NCBI Genetic Reference Sequence Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: One or more characters used to identify the published NCBI genetic sequence that is used as a reference against which other sequences are compared.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Genome Assembly NCBI Genetic Reference Sequence
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An annotated assembly of genome sequences created by the assimilation of data pieces from numerous sources.:Established in 1988 as a national resource for molecular biology information, NCBI creates public databases, conducts research in computational biology, develops software tools for analyzing genome data, and disseminates biomedical information - all for the better understanding of molecular processes affecting human health and disease._A published genetic sequence that is used as a reference sequence against which other sequences are compared.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An annotated assembly of genome sequences created by the assimilation of data pieces from numerous sources.

Concepts.definition: An annotated assembly of genome sequences created by the assimilation of data pieces from numerous sources.

Property.preferredName: National Center for Biotechnology Information Genetic Reference Sequence
Property.preferredDefinition: Established in 1988 as a national resource for molecular biology information, NCBI creates public databases, conducts research in computational biology, develops software tools for analyzing genome data, and disseminates biomedical information - all for the better understanding of molecular processes affecting human health and disease._A published genetic sequence that is used as a reference sequence against which other sequences are compared.

Concepts.definition: Established in 1988 as a national resource for molecular biology information, NCBI creates public databases, conducts research in computational biology, develops software tools for analyzing genome data, and disseminates biomedical information - all for the better understanding of molecular processes affecting human health and disease.
A published genetic sequence that is used as a reference sequence against which other sequences are compared.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Any specific activity undertaken during the course of a clinical study or research protocol.
